content.description: Climb up a crack to an ear feature and launch into the ever steepening wave where you make some desperate moves to a fantastic friendly jug.  Shake out, because it is not over; it will take a blind throw from a thin crimpy rail to get you to the clipping jug.
content.location: From the main trail cut left and walk up the wave wall.  This is right of the 3 lines, equipped with glue ins.

content.description: Climb a steep opening with excellent movement to a series of small crimps.   Then either get dynamic to get to the anchors or figure out how to crimp on a sloping rail. Often wet, but a great route if you can catch it dry.
content.location: From the main trail in, take the left fork.  This is the middle of 3 lines on the Wave Wall

content.description: Ends on Get Railed. Start on sloper rail, make a few moves up semi bad holds straight up and end on good jug. Short and sweet
content.location: Left of Get Railed, last obvious holds before the moss takes over the rock.

content.description: Start on left hand edge and right hand undercling. Figure out impossible static beta, or set feet and fly out to flat shelf. Traverse left and up a few moves and drop. Someone who's inspired can clean the high slab topout.
content.location: Left side of the Wave Wall, just left of the three bolted routes.

content.description: Engaging climbing with some excellent sequences.  Often wet in the spring, get on it in the fall
content.location: Walk left at the cut off from the main trail which will shortly take you to wave like wall.  This is the furthest left on the wall.

content.description: Start as for Get Railed, but bust up and right from a pair of jugs in the middle of the rail. Make a precise, dynamic right-hand move for a Spock-pocket and then make a couple of deadpoint moves on crimps. Finish on a sloping jug in a horizontal crack as you wish that your spring break trip to Joe's hadn't been cancelled. Not a bad climb if a pandemic prevents you from climbing anywhere else. Here's a fun video.As of 8-7-2020 the topout is clean.  While it doesn't add difficulty, the moves are enjoyable.
content.protection: A pad. Two if you want (no more than two pads permitted on Benjamin Button's Badass Butthole Assassin).
content.location: Starts on the obvious rail on the far left side of the Wave Cave. See Get Railed for additional info.

content.description: Fun little route on the right side of Wave Wall.  Start with a couple of big moves up to a techy finish in a dihedral with some finger jams.Unfortunately, this is one where the top will probably be wet much of the year...
content.location: Right side of Wave Wall.  Straight ahead as you walk up to the cliff on the approach trail.

content.description: Start at the far right side of the rail. Bust some sequential moves up to the end of the rail, hit a left hand slot crimp, and dead point up to a better slot. Move left to a jug. Drop off or continue up the tall, slab.As of 8-7-2020, the topout slab is cleaned.  The topout doesn't add difficulty but provides an enjoyable sequence and satisfying fishing to the boulder.
content.location: Left side of Tsunami wall. Obvious rail.

content.description: Sit start a few inches right of the pinchy ledge where get railed starts. Power through 2 incut Pockets then make an easy hop to a good diagonal edge with good holds above. I did not top it out but you definitely could if you spend enough time cleaning the upper slab.Moving from the first pocket to the second pocket was the Crux for me. It took me more effort then Get Railed but if you're good at powerful moves between good holds it might not feel difficult at all.

The furthest right boulder problem in the cave adjacent to the wave wall. Start sitting at a rail with a variety of crimps. Without using the massive pedestal foot to the right, make one reach dependent move to the higher rail, and traverse left to finish the same as Drip. At least as long as some of the sport routes in the area
content.location: Start sitting at the obvious rail, in the far right of the cave. The huge foot/feature to the right is off.

content.description: In the cave adjacent to the wave wall. Start sitting on a good edge and the handle bar hold. Tense, crimpy undercling moves lead slightly left to a reach dependent move to the jug rail. Traverse left to one more big move off of crimps to finish in high horizontal just above the apex of the cave. Drop off, though a top out would be reasonable with some cleaning
content.location: In the cave adjacent to the wave wall, starts sitting to the right of Hot Pants.

content.description: Another short fun one up the big roof on the far right side of the Wave Wall.  Climb a short pock-marked face to a roof, and then follow a sloping rail to get up into the business. Go for the lip and then use the sidepull/undercling on the face on the left to heave up and over into easier climbing to the finish. (There is slightly easier beta going right after the lip, but the moves and rock are lower quality. Go left for full value!)  This is a new route, and some of the rock on this one might be a bit friable, so use caution (belayer especially!). The shelf just below the roof is questionable, as is some of the rock out right.  I knocked off what I could but more may yet still break.  Climb gingerly.
content.location: Far right side of Wave Wall.  Straight ahead as you walk up to the cliff on the approach trail.

content.description: Progressively harder climbing as the angle kicks back up top.  A bit of a one-move-wonder, but it's a cool little sequence, so worth hopping on.  More likely to stay dry than some of its neighbors too.
content.location: Right side of the wave wall.

content.description: Start on good crimps on an orange colored ledge.  Climb through some always wet pockets to crimps.  The original version finished on a shelf above the cave.As of 8-7-2020 the topout is cleaned.  The topout is heady, but mild, and makes this short boulder feel more complete.

The area includes a handful of boulder problems and five short bolted routes (basically roped bouldering!).  The sport lines on the left are nearly always wet except in late summer or fall, but are high quality if you can catch them dry!  The two routes on the right are faster to dry out. The bouldering can be hit or miss, with lines like "Get Railed" usually soaking wet in the winter and spring, and others staying fairly dry that are more inside the cave.
